review:
Delve Deeper: A Mix of Fun Elements

Review:
Delve Deeper is a game that combines various fun elements, earning a moderate 3/5 rating from me. It offers an enjoyable experience with its unique blend of strategy, exploration, and humor. While it has its strengths, there are certain aspects that prevent it from reaching its full potential.

One of the highlights of Delve Deeper is its strategic gameplay. As a player, you lead a team of dwarves in mining expeditions, searching for valuable treasures and defending against rival factions. The game requires careful planning, resource management, and tactical decision-making. The strategic depth adds a layer of challenge and satisfaction as you navigate the underground mines.

Exploration is another aspect that adds excitement to Delve Deeper. The randomly generated maps provide a sense of adventure as you uncover new areas, encounter various obstacles, and face off against different enemy types. The element of discovery keeps the gameplay fresh and encourages replayability.

Additionally, Delve Deeper incorporates humor into its gameplay and presentation. The quirky interactions between the dwarves, amusing item descriptions, and lighthearted atmosphere inject a playful charm into the game. The humor adds a light-hearted touch and keeps the experience entertaining.

However, despite these positive aspects, Delve Deeper falls short in certain areas. The game can sometimes feel repetitive, especially during extended play sessions. The lack of significant variety in gameplay mechanics and objectives can lead to a sense of monotony over time. Additionally, the graphics and audio design, while serviceable, may not be visually impressive or memorable compared to other titles in the genre.

Overall, Delve Deeper offers a mix of fun elements that make it an enjoyable experience for fans of strategy and exploration games. While it may not have the depth or polish of some other titles, its strategic gameplay, sense of humor, and exploration mechanics provide solid entertainment. If you're looking for a light-hearted and strategic adventure in an underground setting, Delve Deeper can provide some enjoyable moments.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐
A Mix of Fun Elements: Delve Deeper combines strategy, exploration, and humor to create an entertaining experience. While it may lack variety and visual impact, it still offers enjoyable gameplay for those who appreciate its unique blend of mechanics.

review:
Another "retro review" of a game I remember enjoying that I think deserves a positive boost.
First, a few counters to some of the complaints I've seen.  The game is currently still available for purchase.  Also, I have Windows 10, and have had no issues getting the game to launch properly.  I tested that again today prior to my review.
Second, this game is NOT EASY, let me just get that out of the way.  If punishing strategy is not your cup of tea, you may want to give this one a wide berth.  You'll be balancing your lust for treasure and crushing rival teams with the desire to survive against the ever-increasing flow of deadly monsters you essentially unleash upon yourselves the deeper you go.  There's also an element of chance involved with every hex you unearth.  
I had put a lot of time into this back when I was actively playing it, not just because the achievements are admittedly a little grindy, but because I genuinely wanted to get better and tighten up my game.  Early on, one dragon was scary as hell.  After a lot of practice, I would challenge multiple dragons to "COME GET SOME!" lol
Yes, I've encountered some bugs before, but nothing serious and/or frequent enough to put me off for too long.  
Oh, and I also need to mention the fact that this game has a level editor.  Something like that is always a bonus for me, even if I don't plan on getting much use out of it.  I appreciate it when developers give you a space to flex your creative muscles in some way.

[h1]Cávame profundo~♥ 7w7[/h1]

...y miname el hoyo(?); trato de darle un poco de gracia al titulo; ya que no tiene ninguna xD

>A Grandes Rasgos:
Este jueguito es un "RPG por turnos/RTS", en el cual encarnamos a un team de enanos que deben de meterse a una cueva a clavar... profundo, siendo un titulo que esta basado principalmente en el multiplayer... lo hace un "pvp" local bastante curioso y divertido... al menos en un comienzo, cuando empiezas a vislumbrar lo mal hecho que esta xD y la flojera de los controles que le implementaron es un titulo "abotargado"  todo es clickeale aqui, para ir aqui, luego clickeale aca para ir alla, y clickeale aca para regresar... no hay una variedad o libertad plena como en los RPGS/RTS promedio... es mas un mero clicker que otra cosa.

>Lo Bueno
-De menos la idea es original... llevar a tu escuadron de tipos y procurarlos es algo interesante.

>Lo Malo:
-En general... es un titulo "completo" a medias...
-No hay un tutorial claro de que hacer, o como hacerlo.
-No tiene una campaña... es como un juego de mesa, que solo puedes disfrutar si lo juegas con algun familiar/amigo.
-Tiene constantes bugs y crash... lo que rompen todo tu avanze en una "partida"
-El humor... no es tan... humoristico xD

[h1]Resumiendo:[/h1]
Es un titulo malo 4/10... el cual puede mejorar mucho, si los desarrolladores  lo pulen (cosa que, desde mi experiencia con los titulos indie nunca va a pasar), le falta mayor congruencia al "gameplay" dar libertades, mejoras, unidades, habilidades... no solo ser un mero clicker; un tutorial claro de que hacer y como hacer las cosas de jueguito, una campaña que complemente al juego "principal" que es un multiplayer... que deja de tener gracia a la hora jugada, y se vuelve una agonia. Por lo que no puedo recomendar esto, hay cosas mucho mejores que jugar con amiguitos al mismo precio... un ejemplo: Terraria.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979982232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6446, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2879, 'last_played': 1665953833}
review:
A very fun little game.  It's great in 20-30-turn chunks, especially with just two players.  Anything less and you don't have too much time to explore the dungeons, especially the larger ones.  Games with more turns and more players obviously take longer.

It's not a perfect game, and has some flaws.  As the games get longer, mobs spawn to the point of getting out-of-control.  One or two bad decisions can result in multiple turns with your entire team down, as mobs (or the enemy AI) camp your dead dwarves, waiting for an opportunity to come back and hit them while they're down to 1 HP.  This situation requires some additional planning and strategy, so it's not entirely a weakness, but there are many times it's downright punishing--even impossible to escape.

Some variety would be welcome.  You can discover items deep in the mines that enhance health and defense, but some power-ups that improve speed, attack power, etc., would mix it up a bit and improve replayability, even if they were "single use" items.  The introduction of spellcaster--weak HP, low carrying capacity, but powerful AOE attacks--would be an interesting addition, too.

All of that said, while _Delve Deeper_ is far from perfect, it IS a lot of fun.  Know that it's not polished, but it is an enjoyable diamond in the rough.

review:
Die Zusammenfassung findet ihr wie immer unten :)

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

[b][u]Strategisches Buddeln[/u][/b]
In Delve Deeper treten zwischen zwei und vier Spieler gegeneinander an. [b]Gewinner[/b] ist der, der am Ende des Spiels, dessen Länge zwischen 10 und 99 Runden einstellbar ist, die meisten Wertsachen erbeutet hat.
Die Spieler machen abwechselnd ihre Züge, welche immer damit beginnen, dass man ein [b]Tunnelstück[/b] frei graben darf. Man darf überall, wo ein bereits freies Tunnelstück anschließt, eines freigraben. Auch beim Gegner, um diesen entweder durch "ungünstiges" Graben zu behindern oder um ihn in eine Monstegruppe rennen zu lassen.

[u][b]Monster, Loot und Zwergenklassen[/b][/u]
Neben Gegenspielern gilt es sich gegen die zahlreichen [b]Monster[/b], die im Untergrund lauern zu behaupten, zu denen unter anderem Goblins, Drachen und Schleime zählen.  Neben dem, was bereits auf der Karte ist, können noch zusätzliche Monster in unbeleuchteten Bereichen der Tunnel spawnen. Um das zu unterbinden, muss der Spieler [b]Lampen[/b] aufstellen, was automatisch am Ende jeder Runde da passiert, wo er Zwerge positioniert hat. 
Tollen [b]Loot[/b] gibt es natürlich auch zu ergattern. Dieser besteht entweder aus Bodenschätzen wie Gold oder Edelsteinen oder aus Artefakten, die es in vier Güteklassen gibt und je nach Wert Gold einbringen oder gar kosten. Einige können zudem die Statuswerte des Zwerges, der es eingelöst hat, steigern.
Zu jedem Artefakt, gibt es zudem einen mehr oder minder lustigen Text zu lesen, wenn man es einlöst.
Da so ein Stollen verdammt tief ist und es teils lange dauert, wieder nach oben zu kommen, finden sich in manchen Levels Abgabestellen für Bodenschätze und Artefakte.
Was ist ein Strategiespiel ohne verschiedene [b]Spielfiguren[/b]? "Mensch Ärgere Dich Nicht".
Dem Spieler stehen geballte drei Zwergenklassen zur Auswahl, aus denen er sein Fünferteam beliebig zusammenstellen kann. Gern auch 5x das Gleiche. Alle drei unterscheiden sich in Kampfkraft, Zugweite pro Runde und Tragekapazität.

[u][b]Leveleditor?[/b][/u]
Ja, das Spiel liefert einen Leveleditor bzw ein Tool, mit dem man eigene Level erstellen kann.
Das gute Stück ist zwar verbesserungswürdig, aber gut wenn man [strike]schnell an Achivements kommen will[/strike] Level basteln möchte, in denen man sich mit Freunden im Buddeln und looten messen kann.

[h1]Grafik, Soundtrack[/h1]

Die Grafik ist in guter, alter Pixelgrafik gehalten. Ich mag sowas einfach. 
Der Soundtrack ist recht atmosphärisch gehalten, allerdings kann es vorkommen, dass nach einem beendeten Match ein nerviger Ton bleibt. Um den wieder los zu werden, muss das Spiel beendet werden. Beim Neustart ist dieser dann weg.

[h1]Zusammenfassung[/h1]

[b]Pro:[/b]
[list]
[*] Taktisch recht tiefgängig
[*] Humorvoll
[/list]

[b]Kontra:[/b]
[list]
[*] man wird unter Umständen aus dem Spiel gekickt, was gerade bei langen Matches nervt.
[/list]

[u][b]Fazit[/b][/u]
Delve Deeper ist ein unterhaltsames Spiel für zwischendurch und bis zu vier Spieler Der Umstand, dass man hin und wieder (selten) aus dem Spiel fliegt, trübt die Stimmung zwar etwas, aber global betrachtet, ist es ein gutes Spiel. Von mir daher eine Kaufempfehlung.

review:
A simple yet surprisingly deep cross between turn-based strategy and boardgame mechanics.At the start of each game you pick a map, set a turn limit, select a starting point (most maps have these be fairly even but some give different starting areas their own pros and cons) then select your five dwarves. Each dwarf in your mining crew can be one of three classes: Warriors who are slow but have the highest health and damage and a moderate carrying capacity (making for ideal guards to block off passages), miners who have a little bit of everything and have the highest carrying capacity, and scouts who carry the least, are fragile, and their low damage is only made up for with a high critical rate but have the highest mobility rate making them ideal for stealing chests (of which any of the three classes can only carry one), lighting tunnels to curb monster spawns, and grabbing valuable ore deposits deeper in the caves.

Once the game starts each player takes a turn placing tunnels (which are preset tiles with various branching paths that must either link to another tunnel or an open space) and then moving their dwarves. When they end their turn the dwarves will leave a lantern or torch to light the tile they're in (if it's not already) and mine one unit from an ore vein if there is one and they have room in their inventory. They may also pick up gems and gold laying on the floor (whether dropped by enemies or prespawned treasure) and collect treasure chests laying about within the caverns. Once their inventory is full, or you simply feel the need to deposit your loot you must send the dwarf back to either your starting point (which will also heal them at the start of the next turn) or a gnomish bank (for gold, gems, and mithril) or an antique shop (for chests) to turn them in and raise  your score (though you only get half value for the latter two options). Once the turn limit is reached the game ends and the player with the highest score wins.

While seemingly simple there is a great deal of strategy involved in all of this, with your choice of dwarves determining your strategy, whether you go all scouts and blitz down treasure in hopes of getting good rewards (all of which are randomly selected from a list and may sometimes boost (or reduce) the stats of the dwarf turning them in on top of increasing (or again reducing) your score) early, a bevy of fighters that are slow to advance but can spread out and easily deny territory while holding their own against wandering monsters, or all miners and stripping the walls of valuable metals and not having to worry about making return trips nearly as often, or carefully mixing up your units to cover all bases. There's also the decision between depositing materials at a nearby dropoff point for half their worth or risking it and heading all the way back to your base for full value, doubling the time it takes to get back on the field but also allowing the dwarf to recover. It is also worth noting that you do not have to attach tiles to tunnels you put down, and can in fact place tiles ahead in pre-existing spaces or attached to your opponent's to help cut them off and make it easier for you to advance later.

Overall it's a rather fun littler game that I'd like to see more of, and while I only played it single player I imagine playing it multiplayer would be even more fun. My only complaints are the fact that the monster spawns can get a little out of hand in long running games (especially if you're slow to breach pre-existing tunnels), and the fact that this only features local co-op which limits the ability to play multiplayer and takes away a lot of the usefulness of the map making function.

(Game received as part of the carnival prize list during the 2011 Steam Summer Sale and have been enjoying it off and on ever since.)

author: {'steamid': '76561197970761123', 'num_games_owned': 2953, 'num_reviews': 896, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1476, 'last_played': 1494744025}
review:
Delve Deeper is a game where you are a team of dwarves and square off against another team of dwarven diggers racing for loot for glory with the dwarf king. 

A couple other reviewers have called it a "Board game" and that's a good way to look at it.  It's not Monopoly, or Ticket to Ride, but it is a board game in many ways.   The problem is... it's not a very good one. 

Much of the game is the dwarves running to different veins to dig up gold and gems.  Then run those gems back to the start point to "Score" them.   There's monsters that attack, and there's three types of Dwarves, a fighter With good inventory, great attack, and slow speed, a Miner with great inventory, good speed, and average fighting, and a Scout with great speed, weak fighting, and weak inventory.   

And to be honest all three are worth having.  Fighters are crucial.  There's always going to be monsters and honestly they're the ones that are going to have to fight any monster other than a slime.   Scouts move fast, so they can grab loot and quickly score it (Especially relics) and the miner is your base unit.  Oddly enough, miners are probably the least necessary, but still worth carrying. 

But the thing is The "strategy" of the game is the weak point.  The other team almost the same moves as you, but worse.  You have mostly different tunnels, you can grow your tunnel any way you want, but the idea is to find veins and mine it, combat between teams is mostly an after thought.  When combat does happen between teams, well that's when the game becomes a real mess. 

You see you're not able to move if you are in combat.  So when your players try to move through enemies, they are stopped. 

Here's the problem.  When you fight a group of enemies with your group of friends, you run into a stopgap.  Assume you win, then the enemies dwarves are downed for 1 turn (any you lose is also downed for a turn)  So the best thing to do is keep one of your guys in the square you can kill them, they will revive with 1 hp.  You'll knock them out and keep them down.  Except then you have an enemy move into the same square, now all of a sudden that square becomes a total mess, your guy might die, and then their guy dies as they revive, and the game becomes a stalemate for those characters.  You can't move away, you can't fight the enemy, you can't survive, so your characters stay dead. 

That type of problem is manageable in a game, it's even desired in a truly strategic game, but overall this game feels like that's almost the default state.  Run for loot, try to get lucky and get better loot than the opponent.  Hope your random item is better than their random item, and so on.  There's very little strategy to this game other than "play well" and then the random numbers will take over.  Maybe you'll find a epic relic and get a ton of money or a poor relic and get nothing.  Maybe they'll find more gems then coins and you'll find more coins then gem.  

Maybe you'll run into a really powerful enemy, and they'll run into slimes.  The point is the game only feels "balanced" when you ignore the randomness of it.  You might win... you might lose, but really unless you colossally screw up, you don't have much agency in the outcome of the game. 

And honestly that could be fun, but I just don't find this game fun.  I like board games I like strategy games, I like a lot of games, but this one... well it's only a couple bucks, but I can't recommend it unless you MUST have a dwarf mining board game to play with friends.  But really ... there's nothing here that's really special, sadly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971838196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 356, 'playtime_forever': 668, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1486146669}
review:
Spielwertung: 6.5/10

Unfaire Bewertungen? Langweiliges Spiel? 
Ein gutes Spiel, aber mit einer langen Mängelliste. 

Zunächst einmal, mein Spiel hatte keinerlei technische Probleme oder Abstürze. Wäre dies der Fall gewesen, hätte ich vermutlich auch ein deutlich negativeres Fazit geschrieben. Ich habe allerdings nur im Windowmode gespielt, wüsste nicht, wieso man so ein Spiel im Vollbild spielen sollte. 

Das Spiel ist definitv auf Mehrspieler angelegt. Der Spaßfaktor dürfte mit 1-3 echten Mitspielern, am besten Freunden, sehr steigen. Das Spiel erinnert an Mensch-ärger-dich-nicht oder Munchkin oder was ihr so spielt. 

Alleine ist das Spiel lustig, aber ohne echte Langzeitmotivation. Die KI ist absolut ok, nicht zu schwer, nicht zu leicht, gut skalierbar. Es gibt aber keine Kampagne, keine Missionen oder überhaupt irgendwas. Das einzige, was man etwas beachten kann, wären die extrem umfangreichen Erfolge für Steam. Diese sind aber für absolute Vielspieler gedacht, zumindest um sie zu komplettieren. 

Das Spiel selber macht viel Spaß. Die Steuerung ist am Anfang etwas verwirrend, aber wenn man einmal drin ist braucht man praktisch nur noch 5-6 Tasten + Maus. Die Monsterkämpfe sind ok, der Loot ist purer Zufall und durch die zahlreichen "negativen" Schätze auch manchmal gemein, aber da es alle treffen kann, umso besser (auch hier wirkt das Spiel ganz klar als Einladung, mit Freunden zu spielen).

Die großen Freiheiten, dass man die jeweilige Rundendauer einstellen kann (egal ob 10 Runden oder 60 oder mehr) ist auch ein großes Plus. Dazu gibt es die Möglichkeiten, verschiedene Maps zu spielen, selber Maps zu bauen oder neu gebaute zu spielen. 

Alles in allem also ein grundsolides Spiel. Falls die Programmierer wirklich Mist gebaut haben und das Spiel auf zahlreichen Systemen unspielbar ist, kann ich das jedenfalls nicht für mich bestätigen. Zum Alleinespielen kann man Delve Deeper sicher für 5-10 Stunden guten Gewissens empfehlen, mit mehreren Mitspielern potentiert sich dies mit Sicherheit. Ich könnte mir jedenfalls gut vorstellen, einige lustige Abende mit dem Game zu haben, auch wenn es sicher genug andere Coop-Titel gibt, die bekannter sind und weniger schlechte Wertungen haben.

review:
I would normally not give a review to a mediocre game but given that it's cheap, original and underrated it's well worth this short review.

Never before have I seen a turn based strategy game that is so different to the meta of turn based strategy games. If you enjoy turn based games and looking for something new, this is for you.

review:
Delve Deeper basically plays out like a board game in a mine-digging setting that somehow proved to be extremely popular a couple of years ago (the setting, not the game).

As such I suppose it's a lot of fun to play with friends since there are tons of ways to sabotage your rivals and it also makes for some satisfying turns when you grab a treasure right from under another player's nose, slay a foul beast and bring home the booty.

However, I never had a chance to play with other people, leaving me with nothing but skirmishes against NPCs. There is no kind of story campaign and as such it just not engaging to play on your own, which is a pity considering how dead of a game it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988858431', 'num_games_owned': 333, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3312, 'last_played': 1460684951}
review:
The most important thing to remember is this is a hotseat multiplayer game. VS the AI you'll just get bored after a while and there's no online multiplayer.

Delve deeper is a light strategy game that combines area control, pressing your luck, and dwarves. There's a lot of randomness with the battles, which generally punishes over expansion. This is a board game in many ways before the whole video game board game thing became cool. There are plenty of maps included, as well as an editor, you're unlilkely to get bored of a specific map before the gameplay. I can't offer better praise than I am still playing this 5 years later and enjoying it. It shows it's age in a clunky UI, but the balance of risk vs reward is seldomly so enjoyably fine tuned. Just be careful for your jerk friend waiting for you to be weakend before swooping in with thier 5 scouts to pick up your hard won mithril.

review: I have to give Delve Deeper a thumbs up. It's basically a board game, and requires board game thinking: cards and pieces and everything. You move around and get gold, count your spaces, open up parts of the area strategically to make you earn more or screw with other players. I played this a while ago and was addicted for a while until that computer died, and I then loaded it up recently to find it still holds up. I got the base game and the DLC because it was so cheap and because I saw the graphics for the characters released free on Open Game Art. I don't understand the low ranking here at all, unless it was the Delver game people lured into a fight about the name after this had already been out. The only bad thing about the game is sometimes waiting for the computer characters to move, but I see now there's a setting for that, so it's my own fault. If you go into this thinking it's going to be an RPG you will be disappointed, sure, but that would be stupid seeing as how there's all the preview stuff available before you buy. If this looks like your type of game, get it. If you want a 3D soldier game with fantasy trappings I'm sure you can find one of those on here instead, and you should.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004423189', 'num_games_owned': 4447, 'num_reviews': 422, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1389050951}
review:
Несмотря на полное отсутствие упоминаний этого в тексте, после первого же запуска становится совершенно очевидно, что игра изначально задумывалась как настолка. Все эти "поворачивающиеся гексы", "состязательный геймплей", плюс упрощённые схватки и совершенно нелогичные для компьютерной игры (но совершенно естественные для настольной) ограничения по весу и действиям... другой версии, зачем так можно сделать мне в голову не приходит.

И вот как настолка, эта игра была бы довольно увлекательна, мне кажется. Подставляешь друзей, тащишь сокровища, убиваешь монстров - красота.

Но только это далеко не "Манчкин". И простота правил и инвентаря (что является плюсом настолки) оборачивается против разработчика, когда ты играешь с компьютером. Лично мне надоело минут за двадцать. После патча и аддона попробовал ещё раз... не-а, не моё совершенно.

В общем, если хочется простенькой ненапряжной игры на десять минут - можете попробовать. Думаю, эта игра неплохо чувствовала (или чувствует?) себя на мобилках. Моя оценка - 6/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041949592', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 605, 'playtime_forever': 442, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 442, 'last_played': 1489101969}
review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a 2D turnbased casual game.



[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

There are resource value options available.
There are neutral enemies difficulty level available.
There are Ai Difficulty level available.
There is a game speed volume available.
There are 10 master volume bars available.
There are 10 music volume bars available.
There are 10 sound effect volume bars available.
You can toggle between fullscreen or windowed mode.
There is no resolution size available.
There is level editor.
You can play the game with a xbox controller.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

The longer the games does, the more neutral enemies will come. Which means, the TURNS will be drastically longer. Because evey neutral unit is going to do move and attack. Trust me... You will encounter more then 20 enemies.. and once it is your turn again to play. You might have wasted 1 minute+. If there is a battle with an enemy. The fight will be to the death. This counts for Dwarves VS dwarves and neutral enemies.

You have to control 3 different kind of dwarves. A miner, a Scout and fighter. All dwarves are able to mine resources but obviously a miner is doing the best job. Once you have selected a spawn area. You will get another screen on the right side and your in-game area's might glow green. Move your cursor over one of these green zones and you are able to make a tunnel at the right side. Miner has the most inventory slots to store resources. Fighter has the highest Health and damage. Scout has the highest movement but the lowest of everything else. There will be better resources the deeper you go, but you will also fight against other neutral enemies. You are able to lit caves to prevent them from spawning. Once a dwarf has a full inventory, It has to go back to their base to unload. All fights are to the death. The team with the most resources will win.


It is a weird calming game. It is competitive but only offline or against bots.
I do find the personal pop up messages all the time during a battle - slightly annoying.
There are neutral enemies.
In-game Tutorial. When toggled on.
There are just some levels - not a campaign or anything. It gets boring quickly.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

IF a dwarf is ending a turn at the dark section, they will place a torch and create light and vision.

Each time your turn start you are able to destroy a small section in the cave.  YOU MAY WANT TO DO THIS, althought its not always recommended. 

-------------------

I Give this game a 5/10

review:
5min of this game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIm4D2XZHI4

this is like a turn based board game
you play as 1 of up to 4 dwarven teams venturing into a mine full of monsters and loot.
you have 5 dwarves of 3 classes (fighters-slow but hit hard, miners-can carry more and hit ok, scouts-fast but week).
each turn you can dig out 1 space then you move your dwarves.
they can grab from piles of loot or artifacts (you can only carry one and when you turn it in it has a random value) without stopping but will need to end a turn in front of a deposit to take 1 chunk of ore or gems from it.
you need to take all loot back to your base or find a bank for it to count.
if you run into an opposing dwarf or any dungeon critters you'll have to stop and attack them.
you win by having the most loot at the end of all the turns.

not everything in the depths want to kill you, here are some things that will help you out.
gnomes - these guys will collect ore & gems for a small cut of the take.
beholders - they will turn in artifacts for you.
fairies - if you start your turn on one of these fields you'll be healed to full health.

author: {'steamid': '76561198106843561', 'num_games_owned': 290, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 847, 'last_played': 1431184481}
review:
Delve Deeper is a simple turn based strategic game.
The tutorial in the game is a big dialogue that goes into detail of what the game gives (building tunnels to selecting a dwarf and point it to a tunnel where he can mine gold).

The game resolve where you can play from 2  to 4 players and the game is decided by how much gold you have earned through mining gold, gem, mithril, loot from defeating monsters/players and relics.
(To play multiplayer. You need to play it on the computer the game is on. Meaning you can't play from over the world. (Which is actually a must for a game like this)).

Before you start you can choose to three classes:
- Miner:
[spoiler]This class can hold up to 6 items for gold, gem and mithril. Can walk 4 steps and is overall the points getter in the game.[/spoiler]
- Fighter
[spoiler]This class can hold up to 4 items for gold, gem and mithril. Can only walk 3 steps and is overall the one who protect and fight[/spoiler]
- Scout
[spoiler]This class can only hold up to 3 items for gold, gem and mithril. Can walk 6 steps and is overall the one to kill weak monsters and light tunnels that is farther away.[/spoiler]

The relics in this game make said classes stronger, but said relic will only have effect on the said dwarf who picked said relic up.
Relics can be turned in at bazaars or the camp (where you start) and might give favourable effects that will last the whole game.
(Relics also have some references to pop culture, Dwarf Side of the Moon as an example).

The enemies in the game (monsters/players) make the game a little more strategic as well with building tunnels.
Building tunnels is optional. you can use it to progress deeper in the mine or give an opening for monsters to attack other players. Making the gameplay a little more fun. Tunnels is at first dark, but everytime you or the other player/computer goes to a dark tunnel. the dwarf will light the tunnel up preventing spawning for more monsters.

Every map have it's set amount of rounds that varies. (creating a map will automatically give an amount of rounds).
making your own map is at first a great feature. Only that you need every hex to be filled to make it truelly playable.
Picking out tunnels without showing what pieces you can select (picking a wrong piece meaning you need to click said hex to redo it). You will be taking a lot of time to create a map. since it's a lot of trial and errors.

Overall it's a solid game and maybe a must for all strategic gamers out there.
But for me I can't recommend this game.

Pros:
- Easy, Fun Gameplay
- Strategic to it's core

Cons:
- Slow Gameplay
- Creating a map is (kinda) frustrating
- Multiplayer is local-only

Feedback for this review is appreciated.

review:
Я не знаю почему обзоры такие плохие на эту игру. Она же очень классная. Ребят, если не любите игры такого рода, зачем покупать? Зачем потом Жаловаться что игра плохая? 
А теперь по сути:
1. Графика.
Кто бы что не говорил, а графика в игре хорошая. Картинка красивая, без лагов

Озвучки как таковой в игре нету (не считая диктора озвучивающего сообщения), но озвучка имеющаяся там подходит под все языки :) +Прекрасная музыка.

Ее, к сожалению, нету. В самом начале трудновато разобраться, ибо много режимов и не понятно что в них нужно делать, но поиграв от силы час, начинаешь разбираться  в этом, ведь а игре все построено на геймплее, а не на текстах.
4. Собственно, геймплей.
Задумка очень интересная, делать что то типо забегов, соревноваться "кто быстрее"  и "кто больше". Это отличная времяубивалка.
9 гномов из 10 (Только из-за отсутствия локализации)

review:
The game gets boring really fast. While it has a lot of potential the potential is mostly lost in the clunky controls and repetative gameplay.

The game consists of building up tunnels to "Delve Deeper" into a mountain. However a lot of your turns are spent either sitting on a mine or returning to base. You have three different classes, the scout who has more moves, the miner which has more inventory and the soldier which has more health. However since you end up using all your dwarves for just about everything, the you can't really take advantage of the class difference. Also since you can't trade between dwarves, you may a scout obtain soldier relics or something similar. 

The controls are by far the worst part of the game though. You select a hexagonal space by centering a giant hexagon in the center of your screen over it. It makes it insanely annoying to do anything. Also it's easy to make unintentional moves when selecting dwarves and moving your camera through the field.

That being said, the game is rather challenging. Even the easy mode AI is a tough fight. Games are not extremely long so you have to make the most of every move. If you're looking to kill some time, you might try this game. However I would not recommend buying it for more then a $1 as it is not a very expansive game.

review:
Delve Deeper is a game about dwarven greed. But mostly TREASURE! Go down there and grab as much as you can for your most exhalted king. And more importantly, get more than the other teams!

You'll go in with five(5) dwarves, and will need to collect as much loot as you can in games that seem to go by pretty quickly. It's a good game to start up when you're bored or don't know what else to play, or just because you want to grab some more of that sweet gold.

Of your team, you can select 3 classes. The slow, powerful fighters. Fast, but slightly weak scouts, and miners who are a bit average at everything but can haul the most loot. Of course, being dwarves, all classes can mine gold, gems and mithril and carry chests of loot out, but some can carry more than others, and some fight better than others. 
And since you are trying to prove you are more loyal to your king and better at extracting riches, you may end up fighting the other dwarven teams as well. 

It's a simple game with solid mechanics, where you start your turn with a tunnel piece you can put down somewhere to expand your tunnels, or to unleash a massive horde of goblins into your opponent's tunnels. After that, you move your dwarves and end your turn. After that you fight with whichever dwarves are in tiles with enemies on them. A simple and easy to learn system with plenty of maps and plenty of replayability. And on top of that, it's cheap too

Worth grabbing whenever you have some cash left over for it. It's cheap, amusing to play, has plenty of replayability(So long as you don't play it all the time) and a most worthy king to deliver all your gold to who occasionally comments on things going on in his own special kind of way.

review:
Изначально, когда я установил игру и посмотрел на неё, я ничего не понял. Выбил карты с неё (собственно, из-за них я и брал по скидке сей продукт) и удалил.
Сегодня, спустя много месяцев,  от скуки установил Delve Deeper  и … залип в неё. Давно я не видел ничего подобного. У меня даже не находится сравнений, игра чертовски оригинальная (поправьте меня, если что).  Да, на картинку эта игрушка не богата: анимация скудна, графика из этохи 90-х. Но в данном случае это и не важно. В Delve Deeper на первом месте – соревнование. Гонка за ресурсы. И, что не маловажно – это инструмент, которым выигрывается сей «забег». Это - мозг. Игра интеллектуальная. В ней нужно всё продумать: из кого собрать команду (сделать упор на минёров, или же на бойцов, а может и соорудить нечто среднее?), куда прокапывать ходы, где и что добывать, идти ли на прямой конфликт с противником… В игре громадный потенциал и большие возможности для создание своих комбинаций и стилей борьбы.
Однозначно рекомендую любителям умных игр. Другим же, увы, сей продукт вряд ли придётся по вкусу.

review:
Delve Deeper (Dig your way to glory with awesome beards!) 

With turn-based strategies not being as popular as its counterpart, Delve Deeper takes a quick and humorous drive into the treasures of the deep caves. Play as a Dwarf mining team to dig, fight, and "cash in" as quickly as possible.

Pro - Fun and easy, simple art design, humorous dialog, light RPG elements.

Con - Maps can be too small or too big, AI can snowball on you fast, and AI moves units one at a time taking forever for one turn.

Verdict - Buy it! It is cheap and really fun. It's good if you have a turn-based strategy itch that needs to be scratched.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032642050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1407672252}
review:
Inicialmente el concepto del juego es prometedor: tienes un grupo de enanos que compiten con otros enanos para ver quien obtiene más puntos en un determinado tiempo (medido por turnos). Los puntos se obtienen excavando, recuperando de los enemigos caidos (monstruos u otros jugadores) o encontrando  minerales valiosos  y tesoros, aunque hay tesoros que te hacen perder puntos en vez de ganarlos. Al inicio de cada turno puedes realizar un nuevo tunel para conectar con otros túneles con tesoros o encontrar minerales. Solo cuentan como puntos los minerales/tesoros que consigas sacar de la mina, ya sea depositandolos en el banco o sácandolos por el campamento base.

El problema es que aunque el concepto es prometedor, el juego se vuelve aburrido a los pocos turnos. Inicialmente pensado para estrategia, el juego termina siendo más bien un juego de azar en el que puedes ganar con una mala estrategia y mucha suerte, y eso en un juego de estrategia es un problema. Para crear los túneles puedes elegir el tipo de capa que quieres excavar y luego elegir el túnel que quieres, opuedes dejar que sea automático y cuando eliges la capa decidir el túnel de entre los posibles que te deja, pero ambas formas son exactamente igual de ineficientes y se vuelven odiosas; la forma de navegar por el mapa es mala y la forma de mover a tus enanos es un verdadero incordio.

Sin embargo el juego también tiene cosas buenas. Las tropas son estratégicamente eficientes, los combates son automáticos y no son excesivamente lentos, gráficamente es bastante decente para el tipo de juego que es, le han intentado meter humor y tiene bastantes cosas coleccionables. También tiene un creador de mapas por si terminas de jugar a todos y quieres nuevos retos.

El creador de mapas es, con diferencia, lo peor del juego. Aunque un creador de mapas siempre ayuda a aumentar la rejugabilidad de un juego, en este caso es más un lastre que otra cosa. 
Para empezar, si quieres tener un mapa bien hecho debes rellenar [b]todas[/b] las casillas del mapa, ya que dejarlas por defecto lo que hace es dejar un hexágono que no se puede utilizar. No existe el valor por defecto, simplemente es un hexágono que ni tiene valor ni es nulo. Ni se puede usar ni atravesar, como nulo pero no. Además. las casillas [b]hay que rellenarlas [u]una a una[/u][/b], una vez por cada valor que quieras darle (es decir, que si quieres crear un tunel con 2 de cada, primero debes crar el tunel, luego añadir los minerales, después añadir los monstruos y por último el tesoro).
Por otra parte, no puedes modificar las especificaciones del mapa. Ni su título ni su descripción ni su tamaño. Si por lo que sea te equivocas y quieres hacer el mapa una línea más profundo, has de crearlo desde cero. Si quieres cambiar el título o la descripción, a crearlo desde cero. La herramienta que crea los mapas no permite modificarlo (aunque es posible hacerlo desde fuera, pero eso es algo que la herramienta debería permitir.
Por último, la navegación en esta herramienta es mucho peor que la del juego y se podría decir que es directamente insufrible, ya que en muchas ocasiones quieres crear colocar un objeto y terminas desplazandote por el mapa.

En resumen: [b]A mi juicio[/b], este es un juego cuyos aspectos negativos pesan más que los aspectos positivos, y que técnicamente tiene errores de diseño que deberían haber sido subsanados hace bastante tiempo, por lo que no recomiendo comprar este juego.

This game is definitely worth the money.  It's fun, interesting and also at times-- completely frustrating.  It has many ways to customize each game, from making really stupid AI opponents to so many monsters you can't move. review:
Delve Deeper is a local 1-4 player game where you play against each other to try to get the most treasure. At the beginning of the game, you choose from 4 different coloured dwarf mining teams (red, blue, green, yellow), each consisting of 5 dwarfs.  There are 3 different "classes" of dwarf, these being miner, scout, and fighter. Each class differs in fighting ability and the number of tiles they can move in each turn. 

At the start of your turn, you can choose a tile from the right side which basically causes one area of the map to be auto-mined, creating a tunnel. Once the tile has been placed, you can move some or all of your dwarfs, having them pick up treasure, mine for gold, and fight monsters or other dwarves. When a dwarf's inventory is full, you direct them to go back to base to off load their treasure. Rinse and repeat until the game is finished.

This is a very simple game, and it's actually pretty fun. Until it crashes. And it crashes a lot. In fact, looking at the forums and other reviews, it seems that this bug has been in the game from the very beginning and in two years since the game's release on Steam, the developers still haven't fixed it. 

Until this bug is fixed, I can not recommend this game.

review:
Though initially a seemingly solid puzzle/tile game focused on acquiring treasure, it quickly becomes clear that this game is not about that. The first few turns of a game are spent strategically placing tiles, optimizing your dwarves' carrying capacities, and defeating a handful of monsters that delay you.

However, less than halfway through the game, you break into the "deeps" levels of the map and out swarm literally dozens of monsters. They dogpile on your team, run around with impunity, and also each takes its own bloody turn to move and animate. At this point, watching the "EVVIL" team's turn process took several times as long as mine and the AI's turns combined.

Worse, there was no way out of this cascading fail state. Your dwarves get up after a turn of being knocked out, but they're at 1HP and will assuredly lose any fight they get into. Of course, they get into a fight every turn, because the enemies are fast and aggressive enough to shut down your entire operation.

A game supposedly about efficient mining turned into a boring slog to pass turns as my dwarves were all continuously incapacitated. Delve deeper is a clever idea marred by terrible balance and cascading, inescapable failure states that remove almost all player agency from the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001014053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 14626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3790, 'last_played': 1500835473}
review:
Delve Deeper is a game which on the surface seems cute and innocent.  However, below the exterior is a game which is deceptively difficult and unendingly fun.

Is the ultimate goal is to make more money for your king than the other team.  You will need to excavate tunnels in order to get at the wealth which is hidden from view.  Where will you dig your tunnels, and what strategy will you use when placing them in order to find the greatest amount of wealth?

There are all manner of nasty things down there which are just waiting to be released so that they can attack your Miners.  Usually they guard large amounts of wealth or the entryways two areas which you need in order to be able to, of course, delve deeper which is where the best of the loot is to be found.  The questions here are, do you risk the attack, and if you do, how many of your Miners will you commit to the battle?  Your Miners can't be killed, but they can get beat up so badly that they will miss the next turn.  That can end up in the cycle where your miner is being killed every turn and therefore cannot mine or escape on tell a group of his compatriots com to his rescue and defeat the monster.  In this instance your Miners are spending their time rescuing, and not mining, whilst your competitor is merrily running up the score in his favour.

Then there are chests.  Chests are gamble.  They can give you a huge advantage, give you a huge disadvantage, attack you (because they aren't really chests but rather monsters in disguise), or they can be worthless old tat.  Will you risk picking it up?  If it doesn't attack, you will need to carry it some distance to turn it in either at the surface or at a turn in location which you have discovered somewhere in your mine.

There is much more to this game than what I have discussed thus far, but hopefully this will give you some feeling for the complexities as you play this game and plan your strategies.  As I stated in the beginning, it is deceptive, and there is much more to it than immediately meets the eye.  If you buy this game (an excellent value for money at the usual price and even better when it's on sale) then I wish you many hours of fun just as I have had, delving deeper!

review:
Interesting board game.

Players take turns digging into the field by placing tunnel pieces and then sending their dwarves down to collect as much treasure as possible. Your dwarves can mine for treasure, but that takes time. Larger caches of treasure can be found by killing monsters wandering around the board, although this involves fighting and is much more risky depending on your team makeup. Artifacts are a form of treasure that can have a wide variety of effects, good or ill, and make the game more exciting. The game ends after a certain amount of turns, where the player with the most treasure wins.

It can be quite fun, but for god's sake find a friend to play this with. That is essentially the whole point of a board game, really. And to all of you who bat your eyes at my calling this a board game: you could conceivably convert this to physical form very easily, with a human dungeon master taking the place of the monster AI.

I don't know why all these other reviewers want this game to be something it clearly wasn't supposed to be. I mean, how hard can it be to talk about this game in the way it was designed to be played?

review:
You know, for a turn based game, this has potential. 

I love the classic resource gathering games, and this is a very simple game that is all about that. The thing that changes this game is that to get better resource, you need to 'Delve Deeper' and dig the deeper areas of the map. The deeper you are, the better resources you get. Beware however, the deeper you are, the bigger the monsters get!

You control where the flow of the game goes as you control the tunnel systems and choose where to build and dig. This can get quite fun because you can link the other teams tunnel to a tunnel that has a Dragon in it.. and its always fun to watch your enemies get eaten by Dragons. 

The flaws of this game are there is no online multiplayer whatsoever, and no LAN multiplayer either. I guess it still is 'multiplayer' but everyone playing would have to play from the same computer. Another flaw to this game is its time per turn. It takes a long time to move each of your characters around the map and then have to wait for your enemies turns. It gets a bit annoying, but this is the price to pay for a turn based game. 

I dont think that the price for this game is justified for the content. Realistically, this game should cost under $1 as it is very small. I dont see much change between multiple matches, and the lack of multiplayer really brings this game down. It does has merit and potential. 

I'd have to give this game 5/10. Just enough to say give it a shot, but not for over $5.00

review:
[b]SPECIAL NOTE[/b]: After reading the steam reviews, if you still want this game, remember this: by going to [u]"options"[/u], then [u]"gameplay options"[/u], you can see an option to modify [u]"game speed"[/u]. Putting this up to 6 will make AI turns much faster and possibly much more bearable for you.

Delve Deeper is a game that may fare much better as a tangible board game than as a digital video game. For example, games of Delve Deeper range from 15 to 25 rounds and can involve between two to four players (human or AI). However, all human players MUST be present at the same computer; this is what hotseat gaming means. Online multiplayer is not possible, though the developers have said this may be a feature in Delve Deeper 2.

Each game can then last from 25 minutes minimum (at fastest game speed) to more than 1 hour, depending on game speed and number of players and monsters on a map. Players (and the AI which controls the monsters individually) will take turns moving their characters throughout the tunnels collecting ores and treasures.

However, the turn-taking aspect WILL turn off players used to faster gameplay, especially if they intend on only playing against AI opponents. During your turn, you will have to move your dwarves individually. This is true for the AI dwarves, so having a maximum of three other opponent groups can drag out down-time between your turns. To make things worse, AI monsters are moved individually as well, and since they can easily outnumber the dwarves from twice to four times as much (which again depend on game settings), time is dragged out much much more.

But all that aside, I enjoyed this game. I enjoyed the tactics involved when each player can add one tunnel per turn to benefit themselves or disadvantage others. I got excited when my dwarves raced against time and foes to deliver the riches before the final tally is made. And when everything goes to plan, I get oh so satisfied when enemies fall like dominoes and my dwarves snatch up treasure like flowers in a field.

And as a sidenote, there is a collection mini-game of sorts: treasure chests contain textual descriptions of named treasures. These descriptions are then added to a "Royal Gallery" you can later peruse for your own very mild amusement.

Ultimately, I recommend this game, but only in a particular circumstance: [b]if you intend to have this game for parties[/b]. If you have a laptop and can set it up at party with little spillage of fluids, you and up to three other game-inclined friends can while an hour or two away, taunting and thwarting and triumphing as you move your groups of dwarves through the deep tunnels. Enjoy!

review:
This game is mediocre, I got it for $1.48 in a winter sale with trading card market money and barely regret it.   

The console controller support is very buggy, sometimes you'll be in the middle of moving a dwarf and the game will just minimize to desktop, and other times it will just crash to desktop with no error.  At the match resolution screen you have to switch to mouse & keyboard to get back to the main menu and then the console controller with not be accessible or detected by the game until you reload it.

No save feature exists mid-match, so if the game crashes say goodbye to the last 20-60 minutes of your life. Trying to complete achievements because 100% achievement completion is your thing, this might not be the game for you until at least save feature or the crash to desktop bugs are addressed.

Beware opening tunnels aggressively on computer opponents so that they are swarmed and attacked by 20+ monsters, turn rotation begins to take forever because each one moves individually  to each hex when it's occupied by a dwarf they are going to attack instead of collectively based on their movement #, or by monster type.  They each attack individually on their invisible initiative count.  Although hilarious to win by having your opponents torn to bits it makes a 20 turn match take 2-3 times longer.  I couldn't imagine playing a 40 turn match without being able to save.

review:
The premise is simple. You build a team of dwarves that dig, collect and fight in a mine to collect the most treasure at the end of a certain number of rounds. You play against other teams of AI or local co-op if you can find someone else who wants to play this game. For the most part it's a strategy game with some RPG elements. Other than directing your team where to mine you don't have much control other than that. 

The fighting parts are played completely by the AI. There are difficulty settings you can adjust but for the most part the other dwarf teams will just try and mine more than you and the random monsters will attack the closest group to them. Another thing about the monsters is that some are also randomly generated during the match. So while you might only see 4 or 5 near you during their turn can quickly spawn an extra 10. This is annoying as you're pretty much screwed when you only have a team of 5 at most and if they aren't 5 fighters you will die rather quick and the monsters will just attack you again the moment you get back up.

Ironically the only reason you'd want to play this game is to mine achievements. There's plenty to be had some harder to achieve than others. There's a good variety of maps and even the option to create your own. This game has potential to be very good but overall an average party mining game but low on the list of games I'd want to play with others.

review:
This game would have been a better board game than a video game. 

It's you versus the enemy (or other players), and your goal is to gain the most treasure by the end of the game. The deeper you go, the better the loot. The game moves too slow to play for 5 or 10 minutes, but it ends too quickly to be satisfying. 

Playing against the computer, I found myself trying to use a strategy of digging as deep as I can to get the best kind of loot. But there's too much randomness in the loot, that I found myself losing really bad. And it's not the choices you make either. Sometimes, you bring up a treasure chest and it had a bomb in there, so you lose 5 gold. And sometimes, your opponent brings up a treasure chest, and it had 10 gold. Not fair. 

This is the Monopoly of video games. Fun idea, but throw strategy out of the window.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996627259', 'num_games_owned': 1878, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1379355406}
review:
I gave this game a shot, I really did. I wanted to like it, and even with it's obvious, glaring flaws, I dug deeper to see if there was something there, but after it was all said and done, there wasn't.

The game presents an interesting idea, and it reminded me of something like Dungeon Keeper. You have dwarves, and you have them mine these caves for you in real-time, collecting resources, which you use to attack the other team. You can find treasures, and different items that give you temporary upgrades for that match, and eventually, one team becomes the victor.
Sound great, right? Well, no, actually.

On paper, the game sounds like it'd be cool, and really fun, but in practice, the controls are just awful. You're forced to move the camera around by clicking and dragging, and issuing commands to your units just feels really cumbersome. The artstyle is interesting for a bit, but once you realize how limited the whole thing is, and how many assets they changed the colors on and re-used. that also begins to lose it's appeal. There is basically no storyline to speak of, and what little bit of flavor text they do try to put in there just comes off as bland and annoying.

I could forgive ALL of these things if the design of the game was fun... but it also fails in that aspect. Nothing I did in the game felt rewarding or satisfying, and I think that's the most damning thing you can say about it. It just feels like a bunch of cumbersome clicking without any payoff. It's a bland, useless, mess of a game, and nobody should waste their time or money with it.

review:
Delve Deeper is a light, entertaining turn-based strategy game in which each player commands a team of five dwarves in a race to gather as much gold and jewels as possible within the time limit. 

The rules are simple and straightforward, and the experience feels a lot like a board game as it plays out. Each turn, you will place a new section of tunnel, move each of your dwarves, and then watch as they fight monsters and gather treasure. Battles are basic RPG fare, and are handled automatically. 

The strategy elements come into play as you decide how to task your dwarves. Each dwarf can only hold a fixed amount of treasure, which must be returned to your base camp (or to a gnomish bank, for a fee) in order to be added to your score. There are also special relics which can be collected; these remain a mystery until they are turned in at camp, at which time they may give you a large boost in your treasure, provide the dwarf who was carrying it a boost to life, attack power, or speed, or even *subtract* points from your score in the case of cursed items.

Strategic placement of tunnels is also important. The layouts of tunnels that may be placed become more restricted as you move from the highest 'dirt' level down through the 'stone' layer and into the 'deep'. If placing tiles carelessly, you might find yourself unable to reach a treasure-laden tunnel in the future. You also have the option of connecting monster-filled tunnels to your opponent's tunnel system in order to distract and delay them.

I played several games of Delve Deeper against the CPU, each of which took 45-60 minutes to play out. I didn't see any way to save my progress during a game; all of the games I played were completed in a single session, but the lack of saving did discourage me from trying some of the larger maps.

Positives:
* Quick and easy gameplay provides bite-sized strategy without a major time commitment
* Charming 16-bit-esque visuals and humorous writing

Negatives:
* No save functionality
* A button to fast-forward through the computer's turn would have been nice

author: {'steamid': '76561198026401875', 'num_games_owned': 1529, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 417, 'last_played': 1582127459}
review:
Maybe it's the beard talking, but I've always liked dwarves more than elves. They don't care about harmonizing with trees and developing anorexia. They're a race of hairy, pudgy alcoholics, and if there's anything in fantasy lore I can relate to, it's going to be that.

Delve Deeper(!) is a strategy game about mining. You command a team of five dwarves as they try to collect more treasure than any other team and win their king's praise. Each turn begins by placing a piece of tunnel into one of the unoccupied hexagons on the map to reveal any treasure within and build paths to yet more treasure (or to connect tunnels containing monsters to opposing teams' tunnels for your amusement and possible gain).

Next, the dwarves are moved. Once a player ends their turn, that team's dwarves hang lanterns where they stand (as in Minecraft, light prevents monsters from spawning), and mine any nearby treasure, fight any nearby enemies, heal, or drop their treasure off, depending on what occupies the space alongside them.

Delve Deeper has a pretty good sense of humor, most often taking the form of the Dwarven King's reactions to the dwarves' success or lack thereof. There's referential humor as well, but it thankfully doesn't feel as though it's being used as a crutch, as referential humor so often is.

The gameplay is tactical, but easy to learn and most certainly fun. Everything from AI difficulty to monster and treasure frequency can be set to meet the player's needs. Aesthetically, the game is quite charming, considering it features a bunch of hairy, pudgy alcoholics. At $5, Delve Deeper is definitely worth a shot.

review:
ボードゲーム。
ダンジョンを掘り進め、敵のチームよりも多くお宝をゲットするのが目的だ。
チームをFighter、Miner、Scoutの3クラスの中から5人を選んで編成する。Fighterは戦闘、Minerは採掘、Scoutは移動に優れる。チームを編成したら開始地点を決めてダンジョンを掘り進めて行くことになる。1ターンごとに自分のキャンプ側のダンジョンに隣接する空きマスに道を作ることができる。このときに相手チームのダンジョンに繋がると、自分のチームのキャラで相手チームのキャラを攻撃して宝箱を奪うことや、相手チームのダンジョンに大きく迂回させるような道を作るなどして妨害することが可能だ。

[ゲーム設定]
AIの強さや出現する宝箱の数など細かく設定を行うことができる。
注意しなければならないのは、初期配置以外のモンスター再出現を無制限に設定すると、モンスターの数が増えすぎてゲームのテンポが悪くなったり、自分や相手チームのキャラが大量のモンスターにレスキルされまくる状態になることがあるので、ほどほどに調整すると良いと思う。

[カスタムマップ]
マップエディタがついており自分でマップを自作することができる。ちなみにカスタムマップでも実績は解除可能なので、実績解除用にカスタムマップを作るのも良い。

操作性やUIに若干の悪さを感じることはあるが、ゲーム自体はダンジョンをどう広げていくか、相手チームどう妨害するか戦略性のある面白いものとなっている。ボードゲーム的な楽しさに興味があればオススメなゲームだ。

author: {'steamid': '76561197961167439', 'num_games_owned': 1579, 'num_reviews': 720, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1403850533}
review:
Delve Deeper was a little confusing at first, but after spending an hour learning the ropes, I found the game does offer some mild fun. It's a short turn-based strategy game where you and up to three other players control a team of dwarfs and compete against one another in search for the most treasure. There's a handful of different treasure types that are worth different points plus collectible relics which can modify your team member's stats. Each game is played for a finite amount of turns (usually between 10 and 30) and the player with the most points after all turns are played wins. Nothing over the top--just short and simple. It's a very similar game style to Worms.

There are three classes of dwarfs each having different stats like hit points, movement points, and inventory slots which you choose before the match. Each team starts at a different mining location allowing you to decide whether to battle your opponents and take their stuff or avoid them and just mine for gold. There is also an evil team which is computer controlled made up of various monsters throughout the dungeon to thwart your treasure collecting efforts. The old school battle system works pretty well with the rest of the game's simplicity.

Now there are a couple game breaking bugs that you'll need to avoid otherwise the game will just crash. When you are on an invalid dig location and click on the yellow area where it says "No Valid Plays", the game will crash. Very repeatable and very annoying, but if you don't click on the yellow area, the game seems to be stable. Also you'll want to turn off the tutorial, otherwise the game randomly locks up during some battle sequences. I found a few forum posts about these plus claims that the developers have moved on to a sequel so there likely won't be any future fixes.

If you can work around these bugs, the game isn't bad. I can't really recommend a game with major lingering bugs, but there is a decent amount of replayability for fun in small doses.

review:
The page on this includes RPG and adventure in the description, but don't be fooled -- it's purely turn-based strategy.  You play on a variety of 2d side scrolling maps which each have a set number of turns for you to find and return the most loot for the dwarf king.  Maps are grid-based and you get to dig one grid deeper each turn.  

You play as a team of five dwaves taking turns against 1-3 other teams.  You can choose a combination of scouts, miners and fighters to compose your team.  They all have different pros and cons: miners can carry more loot, but are weak to enemies and other players; scouts can move more grid spaces each turn, but are also weak; fighters can take down enemies but move fewer spaces and carry less.  Loot is either mined, dropped off slain enemies/players or found as artifacts laying around.  You must use a turn to deposit them at certain grids on the map before they count toward your score.

Plenty of achievements, settings, looks nice and is fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009585682', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 196, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 194, 'last_played': 1409173281}
review:
C'est bien connu, les nains sont d'excellents mineurs et raffolent des trésors, en plus d'être d'agréable compagnie. Ceux de Delve Deeper ne font pas exception à cette règle.

Delve Deeper est un jeu de stratégie dans lequel vous incarnez une équipe de nains dont l'objectif est d'investir une mine afin d'y récupérer le maximum de trésors, qu'il s'agisse de pièce d'or, de pierres précieuses ou encore de reliques. Ce jeu se déroulant au tour à tour oppose de deux à quatre équipes de cinq nains, chacun pouvant être un éclaireur, un guerrier ou un mineur. Les éclaireurs peuvent se déplacer plus loin plus rapidement, mais ne peuvent pas transporter beaucoup de trésors ou exceller au combat. A l'inverse, les guerrier sont redoutables en combat, mais ils se déplacement lentement et ne peuvent pas transporter beaucoup de trésors. Enfin, les mineurs sont les plus équilibrés du groupe, ils se déplacent aisément, combattent avec aplomb et peuvent transporter beaucoup de trésors.

Après avoir choisi l'un des nombreux niveaux proposés, il ne vous restera plus qu'à déterminer la composition de votre équipe et votre point départ. Celui-ci sera important puisque vous devrez y retourner souvent pour rapporter vos trésors, à moins que vous ne préfériez les vendre aux Gnomes et Beholders présents dans la mine. Chaque tour se déroule de la même manière, vous devez d'abord placer une pièce hexagonale de type corridor dans la mine, afin de révéler un nouveau passage, qui pourra être emprunté par vos nains, ou encore par des monstres...au détriment de vos adversaires si vous êtes machiavélique. Cet aspect du jeu est intéressant mais inutilement compliqué. Ensuite, vous pourrez déplacer vos nains afin de récupérer des trésors ou combattre des ennemis et passer au tour suivant. C'est alors que vous verrez vos adversaires et les monstres se déplacer, puis les combats se résoudre automatiquement. La vitesse du jeu pouvant être accélérée, une partie peut-être complétée en-dedans de 15 à 30 minutes.

Points positifs:

+ Graphiques rétro sympathiques
+ Comprend un éditeur de niveaux
+ Très bonne rejouabilité

Points négatifs

- Aucun multijoueur en-ligne
- Interface quelque peu confuse
- Intelligence artificielle limitée

review: If you where to buy any game on steam for under 3$ this holiday season, Delve Deeper needs to be on that list. Delve Deeper is a very dynamic and compact strategy game perfect for fun half-hour gaming jaunts, plagued only by some inconvenient & occasionally frustrating controls.
